headline.main: Hermann Field -- Wartime Prisoner and Novelist, 90

lead_paragraph: Hermann Field, who was imprisoned for five years by Communist authorities in Poland and who wrote two novels with his cellmate before his release in 1954, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Shirley, Mass. He was 90. Mr. Field, who was arrested while in Poland looking for his missing brother, wrote the novels ''Angry Harvest'' and ''Duck Lane'' with Stanislaw Mierzenski. ''Angry Harvest,'' about a Roman Catholic farmer in Poland who rescues a Jewish woman during World War II, was the basis for a film by Agnieszka Holland. It was shown at the New York Film Festival in 1985.
